dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blazing sun. MUSIC everywhere. Everybody's living la vida

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And we're good to go. TWO MEN come out of the BEACON HOTEL. Loud Hawaiian shirt walking a Chihuahua. They pause; take in the scene on Oce Adjust their EARPIECES.

dialogues.speaker: LEOPOLD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Proceed to first checkpoint and hold. They thread their way to the corner... across the street. the Promenade. Under fat shady palm trees, to a CLEARING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGENT STEARNS has a RIFLE with a kick-ass scope. AGENT LE watches through binoculars; talks through a collar mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay sit tight. Company's coming. THROUGH BINOCULARS NOW, as TWO DEADLY MEN approach like barracudas. A THIRD GUY, BEHIND THEM, the KINGPIN they're protecting. Then as TREETOPS BLOCK THE VIEW --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Hang on. Leopold scans, looking for them. Searching, until he FIND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hawaiian Shirt Guys hear that. The SEE the Barracudas getting nearer; steal a look at the roof...

dialogues.speaker: ROOFTOP
dialogues.text: rinses off at an outdoor shower. Beads of spray skip off her like diamonds in the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, mama. She bends, twists; water streams down every delicious cur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sure is taking her time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must be really salty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) It's not just the salt. She's got sunscreen on. Then the sand gets on that, and it sticks... (then still watching) Hell, one time I was in Hawaii? And these three models --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. (looks at him) Hawaii.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Shit! He WHIPS THE BINOCULARS back: but all that's left is the Chihuahua. Then, walking into the spot --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Dave Barry. Has something like this ever happened to you? (bends down to pet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you're a guy - or if you know someone who is - then what you've just seen should look pretty familiar. He picks up the Chihuahua, starts walking with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scientists call this condition "Lust Induced Brain Freeze." It affects millions of guys, every day, in all walks of life -- causing anything from a mild embarrassment, to an international incident. He stops. Finds LEOPOLD and STEARNS and SEVERAL OTHER AGE pointing GUNS at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand over the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. I didn't even know it was a dog. They take it from him; rush it away. Dave turns to CAMERA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Notice I didn't say it's a condition that affects men every day -- only guys. And that subtle but important difference is one of the things this movie is about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HUSBAND and his WIFE. He has suitcases by the front doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never get away with this. I'll sue you down to your last penny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck - I transferred everything we own into private accounts, where you can't touch it. In fact, as of now, you're broke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've fallen in love with another woman. A younger woman. Prettier, with no cellulite. Actually, I think you'd like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bastard. The IMAGE FREEZES. Dave walks into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now clearly, this woman is dealing with a Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whereas Guys aren't capable of doing anything like what you just saw. Guys are more like this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DIFFERENT HUSBAND sits across from his WIFE. Above and behind her is a TV with SportsCenter on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want you to know, I've thought about this a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I've talked it over with everyone I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. She looks down; stirs her soda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there's nothing left to do now, but leave you, forever, and only see you from across a shiny conference table with bloodthirsty lawyers all around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat; turns to her) -- Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Okay?" That's all you have to say? (then watching him) Well then I guess this is it. She pushes back from the table, starts off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This can't be happening... The words she's waited for. She turns, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the tv) How can you dQ that? How can you trade Lupenza? (then to the BARTENDER) What's the matter with these people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats me. I saw this on the eight o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the backbone of the whole team! They're pikers without Lupenza!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you in court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I gotta call Lenny. He takes out his cell phone. She levels a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should call your lawyer too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he could hit left-handed pitching, I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lenny. Pick up -- the Yankees got Lupenza! The IMAGE FREEZES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two OLD PEOPLE on a glider. LENORE talks directly to CAME ALBERT'S absorbed with some device that we can't see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well when I met him, I didn't know so much. About guys, or men or what have you -- we just didn't talk about such things then. In fact, I didn't see him naked until quite well into our marriage. When was it Albert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year ago. By accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway. I thought I was marrying a man, but didn't know that in his heart, he was a guy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: When did you first suspect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not long after the wedding. But it didn't bother me. I just didn't know how to recognize the signs. But we've learned to live with it. Haven't we, Albert? (then after a beat) Albert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's twelve hundred and thirty-one miles from this spot right here, to Cleveland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that have to do with anything? He holds up the device - handheld GPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six hundred fifty-one from Atlanta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares how far we are from Atlanta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a cousin there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert. There's a person here asking us questions. There's a film crew here. He looks up at the CAMERA, as if just noticing someone th Then holding up the GPS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. Where do you live.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Here in Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What part. Lenore buries her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave walks down a crowded street. Colorful day life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a lot of big cities, Miami is known for its sizeable population of guys. So we came here to take the city's pulse on the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young, pretty, single SECRETARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me put it this way. Everyone I ever dated was a male. I mean they were all men. But only some of them were guys. You know?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks about it) -- The guys were funnier. But the men were more responsible. You could almost half-believe them when they told you something sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: So, if you were to meet someone that was funny and responsible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 20-ish HORSE GROOMER talks to the CAMERA while she comb out a mane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well guys, they're sort of like your older brother. And men are like your dad.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your older brother doesn't have to grow up. Your dad came that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave walks out of the barn towards CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now you have some background on basic guy attributes. But before we move on, let's look at one more scene and see where you stand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELAINE works at a window desk. ROGER watches NFL on FOX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- now that's the kind of middle linebacker you like to see. He's got the mud all over him, he's got the bleeding knuckles, he's got the clumps of grass all jammed in his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the tv) Oh man you gotta show that again Shepauses; chews her pen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger...I think I really love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9 ELAINE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks over there) But I can't bear the uncertainty anymore, of where this relationship is going. Roger turns... ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not asking whether you want to get married. Only whether you believe that we have some kind of a future together. That you, and I - have a future. JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now this is just what you want in a playoff game. You got snow, you got mud, you got a lead that keeps changing, you got two great teams that just hate each other to the bone and would rather die than give up... Roger looks...then takes the REMOTE and TURNS OFF THE TV waving Elaine over, who cuddles into him. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking too, Elaine. And for the first time in my life, I'm feeling like I might really be close to a lasting commitment. I haven't said anything up until now because it's always been important to me that I not mislead you. But yes, Elaine. I want to think that we dQ have a future. And with a little more time, I think I could be sure. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Roger... He smiles. Strokes her hair and pulls her in even closer. They share a long deep sigh together, As the PICTURE FREE and DAVE WALKS IN. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this was how you responded, you're not a guy. You may not even exist. (then taking the remote) On the other hand...

dialogues.speaker: POSITIONS. DAVE RESTARTS THE ACTION AS ELAINE IS SAYING -
dialogues.text: ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not asking whether you want to get married. Only whether you believe that we have some kind of a future together. That you, and I - have a future. (then looking at him) Roger? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (engrossed in game) What. FREEZE on her look, and -- DAVE (TO CAMERA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that was you...you're a guy. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHERYL CROW talks to the CAMERA before going onstage. The muffled SOUNDS of the warmup band O.S. SHERYL CROW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well there were always guys at my shows - right from the beginning. I mean you start out playing beer halls, right? So when you have beer, you have guys. And it sorta just grew from there. But I was okay with it. They didn't cause much trouble.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: And what about men. SHERYL CROW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men cause trouble. (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's okay too. I get half my songs from that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: So it all works out.
SHERYL CROW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long as they buy the records... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave walks along the stacks in the ANTHROPOLOGY SECTION. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where did this all start? Many experts now think they know where men came from, but what about Guys? where did they come from? He stops, peels off a THICK BOOK full of science things. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To answer this question accurately, we might have to look something up. So instead we'll travel back to prehistoric sub-Saharan Africa, and get there just in time for the Dawn of Guys. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The endless expanse. A cluster of caves. SOUND EFX of all kinds of nasty shit out there. Skittering over rocks. Slithering through the grasses. Bigger predators, circlin A ROOSTER cocks his head back and CROWS out. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: TNT. ONE OF THE CAVES
dialogues.text: PRIMATE ROGER opens one eye...SEES PRIMATE ELAINE, PRIMAT KIDS and PRIMATE IN-LAWS. Hairy grunting things, all slee in a protective clump...
He rolls over, back to sleep. But the ROOSTER CROWS again CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOSTER, COOKING ON AN OPEN FIRE
dialogues.text: CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRIMATE ROGER comes out. A sleepy nod at PRIMATE GENE and OTHER PRIMATES, as they take up LARGE JAGGED ROCK SLABS leaning against their caves and start off. In a few milli years they'll be leaving suburban driveways this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRIMATE ROGER and PRIMATE GENE have joined PRIMATE LENNY PRIMATE PHIL. All carrying their slabs of jagged rocks. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grunt grunt grunt grunt grunt! (SUBTITLE) 0

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and that's why wildebeests are so mean. PRIMATE GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grunt grunt!0 Ha ha! PRIMATE LENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grunt grunt grunt! 0 That's really funny! PRIMATE PHIL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grunt ...0 I don't get it... The other three look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRIMATE WOMEN work in stooped-over positions, trying to p roots and tend fires while BABY PRIMATES crawl all over t They HEAR the Primate Guys' laughter trailing off. They trade looks; Something seems to pass between them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primates Roger, Gene, Lenny and Phil get to the grounds a SEE PRIMATES PETE and LOUIE already there. These two don' have the rock slabs though.     13 PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grunt grunt?0 Whassup? PRIMATE PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grunt grunt grunt. 0 Nothing. We've been hunting. PRIMATE GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grunt grunt? 0 Where are your jagged rock slabs? PRIMATE LOUIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grunt? ГўВќВ‘ Slabs? (looks at Primate PETE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grunt grunt grunt? ГўВќВ‘ Who needs slabs? Primate Pete laughs with him; then holds up a ROUND ROCK, about the size of a grapefruit. Primate Roger and Primate Gene trade looks with Primate Lenny and Primate Phil. Grunting/subtitles continue.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST FOUR PRIMATES
dialogues.text: Ooooohhhh. Ooooohhhh. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get that? PRIMATE PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primate Discount Manny. He just got them in. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I have a look? PRIMATE PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be my guest. He hands it over. Primate Roger lays down his jagged rock slab to check it out. His buddies gather round. PRIMATE GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you kill an animal with that? PRIMATE LOUIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You throw it.
PRIMATE LENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you don't chase the old ones until they get tired and then hit them with the jagged rock slabs? PRIMATE PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) You can stand in one place all day. And when they go by, you just let loose. He shows a throwing motion. The first four look intrigued PRIMATE LOUIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can carry more than one - and if you're throwing uphill, it rolls back down if you miss. It's so much easier with these. PRIMATE GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm sticking with mine. (then off their looks) We've been using these jagged slabs forever. And you know why? Because they work. And anyway, killing them is only half of it -- how are you gonna skin a wildebeest with that? They look at Primate Pete: Yeah, how? But he's there. PRIMATE PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get the women to do it. They look among themselves. They like it. But then. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? PRIMATE PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm working on it. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRIMATE WOMEN are still, pounding roots and tending f and dealing with climbing PRIMATE KIDS. They HEAR SHOUTS O.S.; gather and go to the ridge where they SEE

dialogues.speaker: RIDGE --
dialogues.text: The PRIMATE GUYS are coming back, without their jagged sl and without any animals. But they are having great fun:

running in primitive patterns, and throwing one of the RO back and forth and chasing whoever has it. It looks like the beginnings of rugby, or Australian Rules Football, in terms of all they need now is beer. The PRIMATE WOMEN watch. And trade looks. Once more, something seems to pass between them... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primate Roger and Primate Elaine try to keep it down for Primate Kids' sake. PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grunting, subtitled) Please don't tell me you got rid of your jagged rock slab. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But these are great! PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you didn't kill anything. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's going with jagged slabs anymore. PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the kids are hungry. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your pounded roots? PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pounded roots are a side dish. They need balance in their diets. (then off his look) And another thing - suppose you do start bringing animals home using this -- who's going to skin and clean them? He looks at her-the SOUND of TOMORROW'S ROOSTER CROWING a CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primate Roger comes out of the cave, with his rock. He gi it such a look.
Then looking up at the sky he hurls it, up as high as he can...

dialogues.speaker: IT'S NOT A ROCK BUT A WINDOWS --
dialogues.text: CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- which ROGER is holding, across from ELAINE on the couc ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hundred dollars? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can hold a thousand addresses. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So can my address book. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can your address book pick up your em-ail? ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No but my computer can. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well this can do both. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For five hundred dollars it should give me a manicure, Roger! It should drive me home from work at night! HOW could you spend that kind of money without discussing it first? On Roger's look...the PICTURE FREEZES. Dave walks in. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a whole list of things a guy is supposed to discuss first. Unfortunately, he never knows what they are until he's already not discussed them. (MORE)
DAVE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a girl it's a pain in the butt. But to a guy - some things just come naturally... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrouded in fog. EXPLORER ROGER scans the horizon through spyglass. Next to him is long-suffering EXPLORER ELAINE. EXPLORER ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well did you ask? EXPLORER ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a shortcut. Explorer Elaine shakes her head. Dave enters. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a very simple reason why guys don't ask for directions. It's because they know that if they do, someone else - most likely Visigoths - will come and steal their woman. CAMERA PANS to the side rails, where a CLUSTER OF HUNGRY VISIGOTHS nod, slobbering, confirming this. EXPLORER ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to get to Colonial America. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of GUYS dressed as Indians are throwing barrels i the water. A COLONIAL REPORTER interviews COLONIAL ROGER. COLONIAL REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and this is your way of expressing the public outrage over the high- handed anti-democratic actions of the British Government in general and King George III in specific? COLONIAL ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks a little nervous) Uh, yeah.
COLONIAL REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might I ask, sir, whose idea was this? COLONIAL ROGER (POINTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy over there. COLONIAL REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one drinking coffee? COLONIAL ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him. His name's Starbuck. He said to get rid of all the tea. COLONIAL REPORTER (NODS; THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. One more question. Aren't those Greek fraternity letters painted on your chest? The Guy looks; GREEK LETTERS in greasepaint. COLONIAL ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do that. (then as the Reporter WAITS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell anyone. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOUR MIAMI GIRLS, ethnically cross-sectioned. LILA. MIA. SIDRA. KARLA E. LILA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's pretty much how it is right now, right? They don't grow up. Or, they grow up, but they don't change. MIA (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to know how to spot a guy, there's your first clue: Look for an otherwise man who did not grow up. SIDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No they grow up all right -- but only just enough - you know? (MORE)
SIDRA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like they'll meet the absolute minimum requirements of being a man, but that's it. The rest of the time they're fourth-graders. Walking fourth-graders. KARLA E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More like driving fourth graders. SIDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With credit cards. LILA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a phone. MIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And give them ten minutes on their own? Or put them in with other guys? Now you've gone nuclear. KARLA E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lot is filled with 60's and 70's cars. Dave gets out a CHEVY VEGA; has mutton-chop sideburns, talks to CAMERA. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In learning to understand Guys today, it's important to remember that these same guys, only yesterday, were just kids. CUT TO :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A table of 8 YEAR OLD BOYS: punching, eating, climbing al over each other. One poor luckless DAD with them.

dialogues.speaker: BURGER KING DAD
dialogues.text: Stop punching!

dialogues.speaker: BURGER KING KID
dialogues.text: We're not punching!

dialogues.speaker: BURGER KING DAD
dialogues.text: You are too punching - now stop! We didn't come here to punch!
They stop; look at him as if he's crazy. Then one of them notices ROGER AT 8 looking O.S.

dialogues.speaker: BURGER KING KID
dialogues.text: Hey Roger's got a girlfriend. ROGER AT 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not!

dialogues.speaker: BURGER KING KID
dialogues.text: Then what're you looking at! ROGER AT 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing! And they start punching again. The Dad looks up - so wear DAVE (AT COUNTER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we can see where even at an early age, guy behavior is already well developed along complex patterns that social scientists have called, "jerks." While girls at the same age are referred to by the same social scientists, as "human beings."

dialogues.speaker: A TABLE FULL OF GIRLS
dialogues.text: They are all chatting nicely, passing out napkins and ket packets making sure everyone has what they need. While th MOTHER that brought them quietly reads a novel. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? Humans. He walks past with his takeout order. As ELAINE at 8 noti Roger, blushing, taking all this punishment because of he

dialogues.speaker: BURGER KING DAD
dialogues.text: (as Dave exits) Will you please stop punching! CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave sits across from a BRITISH GUY with a SUBTITLE sayin "Noted Pediatrician. " He has a laser pointer and a powerpoint presentation.
DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we in the area of Guy Violence, Doctor. SCIENTIFIC EXPERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well first, one must understand the inherent differences in DNA and cell structure as relates to men and women. (CLICKING SLIDES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For example, all women have a gene that makes them have the need for meaningful conversations. Likewise, all men have a gene in them that we scientists believe is directly related to violence. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what can be done about that. SCIENTIFIC EXPERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: well, some of my esteemed colleagues are quite keen on the idea of tampering with the DNA itself - an idea with which I heartily disagree. The bastards... DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what would you recommend. SCIENTIFIC EXPERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Well they can start by spreading out the funding a little bit. Let a few other scientists wet their beaks. I mean what's the point of rewarding the same tired old hacks, year after YEAR -- DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant about Guy Violence. SCIENTIFIC EXPERT OH --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (then shifting back) Well nothing, really. I mean, what can you do. Short of lobotomizing them, anyway. No I suppose we'll just have to continue to channel their aggression into socially acceptable outlets. Like professional wrestling, or the space program. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Can I ask you a question?
SCIENTIFIC EXPERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get that laser pointer. SCIENTIFIC EXPERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mine. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave stands in front of the entrance. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of work has been done in the field of children's toys and how they unconsciously reinforce gender roles. Studies have found that over ninety-three per cent of this work is done by researchers who don't have children of their own. But to test the theory anyway, we're here at Toy World Warehouse Planet. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave shepherds new father GENE up to the CUSTOMER HELP counter. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! My friend here is looking for toys for his son that are gender neutral, environmentally sound, and culturally unbiased! SALES GUY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is. He brings up a box with a picture of a spinning top on it

dialogues.speaker: NEW FATHER GENE
dialogues.text: What's it do? SALES GUY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's recyclable.

dialogues.speaker: NEW FATHER GENE
dialogues.text: Where are the trucks and guns. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Father Gene meets up with NEW MOTHER KELLY at the car She came from GROCERY WORLD; he helps load up the bags...

dialogues.speaker: NEW MOTHER KELLY
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: NEW FATHER GENE
dialogues.text: (looks, sees the toy STORE BOX)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I got that for Benjy.

dialogues.speaker: NEW MOTHER KELLY
dialogues.text: You were supposed to get a rattle.

dialogues.speaker: NEW FATHER GENE
dialogues.text: All the rattles were recalled.

dialogues.speaker: NEW MOTHER KELLY
dialogues.text: So you bought a tank.

dialogues.speaker: NEW FATHER GENE
dialogues.text: Wait'll you see what this can do, baby. Benjy's gonna love it.

dialogues.speaker: NEW MOTHER KELLY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Can he shake it? Will it rattle?

dialogues.speaker: NEW FATHER GENE
dialogues.text: Rattle? This thing'll bring down a bookshelf! She looks at him. He'll be returning the thing within seconds. CAMERA PANS to Dave, who shrugs. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rundown place with junked cars out front. ED's an inten little guy in a Tigers' hat and a couple major tattoos. ED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm into fireworks. I like to take 'em apart, you know. And study 'em. See what makes 'em tick.
He shows Dave a box with ASSORTED FIREWORKS inside. ED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got these from Ohio. I don't think they're as good as the ones I got from Tennessee. Not as loud, you know? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well no, if loud is your -- ED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to hear loud - listen to this. He goes over to a different box, takes out what looks lik stick of dynamite. Gets ready to light it; turns to CAMER ED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may want to step back a couple hundred yards. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ed's Auto Shop recedes in the background - with a LOUD EXPLOSION accompanying - DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when we see guys like Ed, and his fireworks - or guys shooting marine flares into innocent pumpkins, or building catapults that'll throw a Buick - we should not condemn them. We should not assume these are just pointless juvenile activities. Instead we should be convinced they are, and move on to Guys in the Workplace. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PHILADELPHIA GIRL stands outside a CHEESESTEAK PLACE. PHILADELPHIA GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys at work? Or guys doing work. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PHILADELPHIA GIRL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean unless you want to talk about faxing or emailing their stupid jokes back and forth. Sick jokes. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave and a SEASONED BROKER eat HOT DOGS from a CORNER CAR BROKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten, fifteen years ago? A guy would call you up with some joke he just heard. So you wanna pass it on, it's by phone. One person at a time. Then a while later, some guy calls you up with the same exact joke. Then when group faxing came in, it really sped things up. Next thing you know there's like ten faxes on your machine, from places you never even heard of. Places around the world, I'm saying. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how long would that take. BROKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A run of the mill, 'guy walks into a bar' joke, those'd take about .a. week to come back to you. The topical ones, your mass murders and tragic accidents and the like, they're naturally gonna have a lot more heat on them and they'll circulate a lot quicker. I mean no one's gonna sit on a Princess Diana joke until three weeks after the crash. No one i know, anyway. (THEN CHEWING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there's the internet -- and what used to take a week'll take like seconds. I'm telling you it's getting harder and harder to keep up. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of people don't understand the attention and the kind of importance these jokes have. BROKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who. (MORE)
BROKER (CONT'D) (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you mean women? Well, you know - what's the importance of having fifteen pairs of shoes? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one knows that. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger is slumped across the back seat; messed-up clothes in obvious pain. Elaine drives; talks to CAMERA. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I get this call at work. (then to Roger back THERE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to tell this? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its just a sprain. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) I get on the phone and they say he's okay - but maybe I should come down to the paper and get him. Does he look okay? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a sprain. It just looks worse. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the way I heard it. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: TNT. NEWSPAPER BUILDING
dialogues.text: Roger's at his desk; can't help but HEAR PATRICK, TOM and GENE talking nearby. PATRICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's how old? TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High school. A sophomore.
GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big deal. I could run the forty that fast. TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and who - the Flash? This kid set a national record. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What nation. BACK TO:

dialogues.speaker: TNT. ELAINE'S CAR
dialogues.text: ELAINE (TO ROGER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something. If the article was about a poem there wouldn't be an argument - would there. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would there be an article about a poem. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying. I don't see the four of you fighting over who can write the better sonnet. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So no one gets hurt writing sonnets. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off her look; then) It's a sprain. BACK TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger listens more agitated as the argument mounts. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you last run the forty? PATRICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. I could beat you in the forty running backwards.
TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't even beat your butt running backwards. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from his desk) Will you guys cut it out? They stop. Look at him. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid in the story's in high school. You're not. You're supposed to be adults and you're bragging about who can beat who in a stupid footrace. TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's bragging. PATRICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene's just saying he can run the forty in under six seconds. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. I can do it in under six seconds. FREEZE THE PICTURE, on their expressions. BRING UP "CHARI

dialogues.speaker: OF FIRE" MUSIC
dialogues.text: DISSOLVE T0:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FOUR GUYS crouch in their starting stance. A SECRETAR stands at the end of a marked-off course with a stopwatch and a whistle. She blows the whistle. They're off.

dialogues.speaker: SLOW MOTION WITH MUSIC
dialogues.text: All four guys explode off the line. Patrick gets five str and goes down. Tom gets two more and falls, howling in pa Then Gene and Roger, neck and neck for at least three mor strides until Roger HEARS A "POP," that ECHOES over the m and goes toppling down. As Gene finishes alone - gripping his side in awful pain but pumping his fist in victory.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC FADES AS
dialogues.text: DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine comes in; Roger, limping and leaning heavily on he ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I listened to you. You need to see a doctor. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a sprain, Elaine. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger you can't walk. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll work itself out. She gives him a look. Parks him long enough to close the door behind him. Without her support, he drops to the flo She turns to the CAMERA. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why won't they go to the doctor? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: British, white coat, stethoscope. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's why. He holds up a RUBBER GLOVE. Dangles it harmlessly. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care who they are. If they think there's even a chance their doctor will use one of these - and they always assume there is - they won't come in. (MORE)
DOCTOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puts it away, shakes HIS HEAD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's anything out there that would bring them in... it hasn't been invented yet. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says so on the SIGN. ANOTHER SIGN, like an internation road sign, has a graphic of a HAND IN A RUBBER GLOVE with RED LINE through it. There are also SPORTS TEAM BANNERS. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR checks a GUY'S chart. There's a TV with ESPN o in the exam room. GUY DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What seems to be the problem? GUY PATIENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well the main thing is, I keep coughing up blood. And I get these really severe chest pains, and double vision sometimes. And every night at sunset, little worms come burrowing out of my skin. GUY DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a sprain. GUY PATIENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I thought. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karla E, Mia, Lila and Sidra again, with Dave. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot has been said about how guys don't share their feelings.     31 KARLA E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean they have them? MIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or they have them and don't acknowledge them. LILA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or they don't think that others have them. SIDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or they just don't think. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they agree on THAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Is it possible that they do have feelings, they do acknowledge them and they do know others have them - but they just don't express it the same way? Four blank faces look at him. Then. KARLA E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sports. They have feelings about sports. LILA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And their underwear. (POLLS THEM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever try and throw out their underwear? MIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once. I nearly lost my life. SIDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They act like it's so sacred. I've seen pairs of briefs with holes in them larger than the leg holes. (as the others nod) I tried to throw a pair out once? And sneak it past him? He went out into the garbage and found them. He said he couldn't trust me after that. KARLA E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me what that's all about. SIDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even want to think about it.
DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off their reactions) So you agree then, that guys at least have feelings. MIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just waste them. That's all. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROGER and ELAINE get out of Roger's car. Elaine has an armload of magazines. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now remember. Gene's dad is real sick. Kelly says he doesn't talk about it. So see if you can draw him out. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He already did talk about it. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? What did he say? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said his dad is real sick. She gives him a look. Gets to the door. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are those? ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelly's boss is turning forty. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're giving her magazines? ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look; then) Just see if you can get him to talk. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a GAME on. Gene sort of stares. Roger has a SHOEB on his lap; goes through Gene's SEGA cartridges.
ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galaxians. Far out... GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (while Roger keeps LOOKING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe the Yankees got Lupenza. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get everybody. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. They suck. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Silence. Roger pulls out two cartridges, compares them. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to Level 24 of Arkanoids. ROGER (TURNS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You're kidding. Gene shakes his head. He's not. This is big. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen the Evil Presence? (then off his look) What's it look like? Gene shrugs; even the best of friends. Roger understands. CAMERA PANS to Dave. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe it or not, ladies - that was sharing. (then nods to kitchen) And believe it or not, guys - so is THIS -- CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine and Kelly with magazines and writing pads. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't know. How do you think she feels about getting older?     34 KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I know how I felt. How did you feel about it? ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does anybody feel. KELLY (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think she'll want a smaller gathering? ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well if we go that way, we know who to invite. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then who do we not invite. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. And how are they going to feel about that. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So maybe we should make it a slightly larger gathering. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Depends on the food, I guess. I mean, if we go with a larger gathering... KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finds the right MAGAZINE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw something earlier in here about low-fat hors d'oeuvres. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - I've seen that one too. They open to the article, scanning it. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm.
ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thinking what I'm thinking? KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That if we have low fat hors d'oeuvres she'll think we noticed she's gaining weight? ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. KELLY (CONSIDERS THAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe just blow it out, you know? I mean it's a party. Go with the high fat. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking she won't think we've noticed the weight gain. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless she thinks that's insensitive. You know, that we hadn't noticed... ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm... They close the magazine, look through the others when: KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about medium fat hors d'oeuvres? ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we could cut them into smaller pieces? KELLY (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could think we were being cheap. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how would she feel about that... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger and Gene watch a PORSCHE COMMERCIAL without the sou GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one has the GPS. With the screen that has maps of everything?
ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about with the convertible. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's optional on the convertible. Unless you get the turbo, then it's standard. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil Wonkerman got the turbo. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit...Phil got a Porsche? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said it was his birthday present to himself. GENE (IMPRESSED; THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was his birthday. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats me. Probably around the same time when he got the car. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit... (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should get him something. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him) He just got a Porsche. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. They look at the TV again. Then, from the kitchen doorway ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger? They turn. Elaine gives Roger a look. PICTURE FREEZES AS:
DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger met Elaine at a company event. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEOPLE with NAMETAGS mingle with drinks and appetizers. Dave comes away from the hot buffet table with a great ha DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- They discovered they had something in common right away. He points to ROGER and ELAINE, over by a tiki-torch. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding! That was you? At the Burger King? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in fourth grade. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was too! But my God, you remembered that? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off Roger's nod) She loved that he remembered that. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GLOW-BOWL night; neon and black light and MUSIC. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing out shoes) A few nights later, he asked her out. He points over to the LANE where they're bowling. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had a good time, and so he asked her again. And then before too long they were seeing each other regularly, and not seeing anyone else. (MORE)
DAVE (CONT'D) (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, Elaine was the only one who knew that... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger opens Elaine's door for her, then goes around. She lingers, watches him before she gets in. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing... She smiles; gets in. Roger pauses. CAMERA PANS TO DAVE. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger has no idea that this was a defining moment for her. Roger gets in. Fuzzy but not sure why. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger drives. Elaine looks out ahead. Long stretch of roa and no one on it. She turns; looks at him. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize that, as of tonight, we've been seeing each other for exactly six months? CAMERA HOLDS on her. She waits.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE'S INNER VOICE
dialogues.text: Gee...I wonder if it bothers him that I said that. Maybe he thinks I'm trying to push him into some kind of obligation that he doesn't want, or isn't sure of. Maybe he's been feeling confined enough by our relationship as it is... CAMERA PANS TO ROGER.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER'S INNER VOICE
dialogues.text: Six months...     39

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE'S INNER VOICE
dialogues.text: He's worried. (then thinking about IT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well hey - you know? I'm not so sure I want this kind of a relationship either. Sometimes I wish I had a little more space, so I'd have time to think about whether I really want us to keep going this way. I mean, where are we going? Are we just going to keep seeing each other at this level of intimacy? Are we heading toward marriage? Toward children? Toward a lifetime together? Am I ready for that level of commitment? Do I really even know this person? CAMERA PANS TO ROGER.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER'S INNER VOICE
dialogues.text: So that means it was...let's see... February when we started going out, which was right after I had the car at the dealer's, which means ... lemme check the odometer... (he looks down at it) Whoa! I am way overdue for an oil change here. CAMERA PANS TO ELAINE. An OVAL IMAGE OF HER APPEARS in th top corner of the screen; they watch him together.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE'S INNER VOICE
dialogues.text: He's upset. I can see it on his face.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE'S OVAL IMAGE
dialogues.text: You know, maybe you're reading this completely wrong - and he wants more from the relationship.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE'S INNER VOICE
dialogues.text: (CONSIDERS IT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More intimacy...more commitment... (AND THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and maybe what's happening, is he's sensing my reservations?     40

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE'S OVAL IMAGE
dialogues.text: Well don't bet the farm on it. But --

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE'S INNER VOICE
dialogues.text: -- And that's why he's so reluctant to say anything about his own feelings - he's afraid of being rejected... CAMERA PANS TO ROGER.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER'S INNER VOICE
dialogues.text: And I'm gonna have them look at the transmission again. I don't care what those morons say, it's still not shifting right. And they better not try to blame it on the cold weather this time. What cold weather? It's eighty-seven degrees out, and this thing is shifting like a goddam garbage truck, and I paid those incompetent lowlife bastards six hundred dollars. CAMERA PANS TO ELAINE.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE'S INNER VOICE
dialogues.text: -- He's angry. And I don't blame him. I'd be angry too. God, I feel so guilty, putting him through this, but I can't help the way I feel. I'm just not sure.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE'S OVAL IMAGE
dialogues.text: (TO ELAINE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what your problem is? You're too idealistic. You're waiting for some knight to come riding up on his white horse, when you're sitting next to a perfectly good person, a person you enjoy being with, a person you truly do care about, a person who seems to truly care about you. A person who is in pain because of this self-centered, schoolgirl fantasy that you insist on clinging to. CAMERA PANS TO ROGER. His OVAL IMAGE APPEARS; at the LOCA BAR with a beer in front of him and pool tables in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER'S INNER VOICE
dialogues.text: They'll probably say it's only a ninety day warranty. That's exactly what they're gonna say, the scumballs.     41

dialogues.speaker: ROGER'S OVAL IMAGE
dialogues.text: Let 'em say what they want. You don't have to listen. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER'S INNER VOICE
dialogues.text: You know you're right. They want a warranty? I'll give them a goddam warranty. I'll take their lousy warranty and stick it right up their -- ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger. ROGER (STARTLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- What? ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't torture yourself like this. Maybe I should never have... (BREAKING DOWN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, I feel so... ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks over, alarmed) WHAT --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She struggles to keep control. Her OVAL IMAGE disapproves ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm such a fool. I mean I know there's no knight. I really know that. It's silly. There's no knight, and there's no horse. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no horse? He looks up; his OVAL IMAGE SHRUGS; gets up off the stool ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm a fool, don't you? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacting to the Oval ROGER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- no! He looks over at her; not sure who he responded to...but appears he said the right thing anyway.
ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just.. .well I need ...time, I think. I think I need some time. Roger looks up at his OVAL IMAGE: gone. He looks at Elain ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Time. Yes. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moved, touches his HAND)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Roger, do you really feel that way? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What way? ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About time. Do you feel that way about time? Roger looks confused. His OVAL IMAGE is off playing pool now. He turns to Elaine; does his best to look decisive. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well. Yes. Yes I do, feel that way. About time. ELAINE (MELTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Roger. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Thank you. They smile. Look forward. He looks a little nervous. She looks serene... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger drives away. Elaine goes into her building. Already dialing her cell phone...
BLAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Kelly -- pick up. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .while Roger and his OVAL IMAGE watch an OBSCURE FOREIGN SOCCER GAME. Share a giganto bag of Doritos. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ref - look alive. Those guys were offsides.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER'S OVAL IMAGE
dialogues.text: They suck. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, the Albanians or the Moroccans.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER'S OVAL IMAGE
dialogues.text: They both suck. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. He eats some more Doritos. But then suddenly-he pauses. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I missed something back there.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER'S OVAL IMAGE
dialogues.text: Wait for the replay. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) No I mean in the car.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER'S OVAL IMAGE
dialogues.text: Can't help you. I was shooting pool. Roger looks up at his Oval Image. It shrugs. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine huddles with Kelly. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .and you said 'there's no knight.'
ELAINE (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and no horse. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say 'no knight and no horse,' or 'no horse and no knight?' She looks at Elaine.. This is crucial. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said 'no knight.' And then I said 'no horse.' (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he agreed to the knight. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But maybe not the horse. Elaine racks her brain; just can't say for sure. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably not important... (then watching her) This is really it for you. Isn't it. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at her; nods) Really it. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glad for her) Does he know it? Elaine looks up; she has no idea. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger and Gene get ready for some 1 on 1. Roger passes to Gene... ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check. .who passes it right back. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check.
Roger takes the ball, dribbles, almost starts but doesn't Gene looks at him. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat; then) -- Elaine and I. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine and you what. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat; then he shrugs) We sort of have this -- thing. He looks at Gene. Conveys the full impact of this. Then - ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she ever mention owning a horse? GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine. She ever talk about horses? Like, to Kelly or something? GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I know of. Why? Roger thinks.. .then shakes it off. Throws the ball to Ge ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the score. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't started yet. They start to play. CAMERA FINDS DAVE, on a nearby bench. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger's in love. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHERYL CROW takes a break in the MIXING BOOTH.
SHERYL CROW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can sympathize with your friend, man. I've seen a lot of guys go there. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any advice for a guy in love? SHERYL CROW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know - most of my songs are about guys out of love. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. SHERYL CROW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause you know, a guy in love - a guy who's where your friend's at, anyway - they don't know where they are. They're like an ant, standing on a truck tire. They don't know how they got there - all they know is that's not where they were a minute ago. But then they sort of get vaguely okay with it, you know? They start hangin' out there, they're feelin' pretty good. (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until the thing starts moving. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens then. SHERYL CROW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then they get crushed. Dave gulps. She shrugs. SHERYL CROW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rock and roll, my friend. Life in the city. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: November 8, 1960. The day John Kennedy beat Nixon and won the White House. That was the day I met her. His WIFE turns, looks at him funny.     47 OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was close the whole way - it was neck and neck by God. But then old Kennedy Senior rode on in on that big old pile of money of his, and fixed the results in Illinois. And that made all the difference. Happiest day of my life, just about. She watches him. The man is hopeless. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was walking away from a newspaper stand, with my head buried in the final edition. And I looked up, and there she was. (he looks over at his WIFE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were wearing a yellow sun dress and there was a smudge of makeup just over your left eye. He smiles at her. Gets a thin smile back. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't me. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it was you. What are you talking about? OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was your first wife. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. OLD LADY (TO CAMERA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We met in Sacramento. Eight and a half years ago. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't believe her. OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never owned a yellow sun dress in my life. And even if I did, I wouldn't be wearing it in November.
OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off her look) -- The point is, in 1960 an Irish Catholic could be elected president of this fine country, as long as his father was a filthy rich rum-runner with connections to the Mafia! And when Nixon did get elected, he had to quit! His wife shakes her head. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelly and Gene on the sofa. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we didn't know each other. I mean, of course we didn't - we hadn't met yet. But we were both invited to the same party, by different people who we only knew marginally - only the party got cancelled, and I guess that's how marginal we were, because no one told us. So we came in different cars and found ourselves at the same front door - with no one home. (then taking his hand) So Gene asked me out to eat. GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hungry. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were in love. (then off his look) You told me you loved me, that first night! GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I loved mashed potatoes. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were eating mashed potatoes. You said you loved me. You said because your name was Gene and mine was Kelly, that that just proved it. We were meant to be together.
GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off her look; then TO CAMERA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Does this have to go in the movie? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GENE AND KELLY'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Dave walks out, talks to the CAMERA. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contrary to what many women believe, it's fairly easy to develop a long term, stable, intimate and mutually fulfilling relationship with a guy. As long as this is the guy: QUICK SHOT OF A LABRADOR RETRIEVER -- PANTING, FRIENDLY. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With human guys, it's extremely difficult. This is because guys don't really grasp what women mean by the term 'relationship.' CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A JERSEY GIRL on break at a SNACK HUT. JERSEY GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I don't get is how they can be a fully grown adult male and not be able to make a commitment to a woman who loves him like no one else - and yet the same person, at age seven, could make an unbreakable lifelong commitment to the San Francisco Giants, who do not even know him and who never will. (shakes her head) I just don't get it. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SEATTLE GIRL outside the cafe.
SEATTLE GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're never "ready." If you ask me, guys are in a permanent state of nonreadiness. That's where they live. If guys were turkey breasts, you could put one in a 350 degree oven on the Fourth of July and they still wouldn't be ready in time for Thanksgiving. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OWNER arranges titles on a display outside her store. CHICAGO GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing is, you shouldn't even think about marrying them until you really know them. But you can't really know them until you marry them. (then after a beat) That's the thing. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Manhattan Girl gives a world-weary look. MANHATTAN GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One: A guy will have sex with anything. Two: A guy will do anything to have sex. There's your Guy Fidelity. Move on. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine and Roger are inside, looking at the front door. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, it's 'supposed to be that way.' It's stuck.     51 ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's basic physics, Elaine. Wood expands. And then, later, it contracts. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we can't get out. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which also means other people can't get in. That's part of the design - it discourages burglars. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him) The same way the toaster was designed to discourage carbohydrate consumption by bursting into flames? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was an outdoor toaster. It was clearly not designed for indoor situations. The PICTURE FREEZES. DAVE steps in front, talks to CAMERA DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's obvious here, that Roger has absolutely no idea what he's talking about. But Guy Pride forces him to keep acting like he does know, for reasons I believe we've covered in an earlier scene. He nods his head over to the corner, where the CAMERA PAN TO SEE HUDDLED VISIGOTHS, WAITING. Then BACK TO ROGER AND ELAINE as the PICTURE UNFREEZES. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. So now we have a broken water heater and a stuck front door. (CONTROLS HERSELF; THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's time to call Steve. ELAINE'S IMAGE FREEZES. Roger turns to the CAMERA.
ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Steve." CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE leaves someone's house, heads for his super-outfitt TRUCK. Haloed in golden sunlight. Strong, capable, equipp for every situation. WOMEN look out from kitchen and bedroom and living room windows, from front steps and yards and gardens, just to whose house Steve is leaving. The women look all dreamy t way they would in a really corny musical. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching; to CAMERA) As far as women are concerned, God didn't really rest on the seventh day. On the seventh day, God created Steve. As the Women all sigh... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine stands at the basement door. CLANGING down there. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger? Did you find anything?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER IN THE BASEMENT
dialogues.text: He's in ankle deep water. Pokes a FLASHLIGHT into some of the corners where the overhead bulb doesn't reach. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good news, honey! The basement's level. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you tell? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I know a well built floor when I see one! We were right to buy this house. Everything works just the way it should!
ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except there's no hot water. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aiming the flashlight) Sweetheart, don't you remember? The power company talked about this. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about calling Steve. ROGER (HATES THIS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll call "Steve," when we have a real problem. Okay? (then more to himself) A mouse gets the hiccups, you don't have to call Steve every time. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hears him whang something down there) But Roger you're such a good copy editor. You don't have to be a good repairman too! Honest! ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay I think I found it. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The water heater. Elaine leans her head against the door jam. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine sits on the step, looking blank. Kelly is with her There are LOUD NOISES from the basement. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why he does this. He doesn't know what he's doing down there... KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be all right.
ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off a loud CLANG) It's not like some broken part is just going to be standing there, waving a flag that says "Help me." Or there'll be an octopus on the compressor, and then he could say, "Look! There's an octopus on the compressor!" (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, how would he know it was the compressor... KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, it'll all work out. After a while, there's no more harm they can do. Roger comes around from the side door. SLOSHING feet. Hol a dripping PART. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need to go to the hardware store. Hi Kelly. Kelly smiles, waves. Then as Roger sloshes past, to the car. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is it about the hardware store? All they do in there is buy a bunch of tools that they don't know how to use -- and no matter what the problem is, all they'll end up doing is whacking at it with a hammer until it breaks even more. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then they cover it all up with duct tape and then come out and say it's supposed to work that way. ELAINE (SOLIDARITY NOD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we have to call Steve. And they get offended. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger waits at the counter. Talks to CAMERA.
ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something. If I had a dollar for every time I heard "Steve's" name, I could hire somebody better than Steve, just to shake things up. Get her one of these old semi-retired guys - someone from the pre-steroid days, with the hairy shoulders, and the butt crack. They won't be so quick to call him every ten minutes. The Clerk comes back. Hands over a 53-piece TOOL SET. CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember. Keep these away from anything magnetic. ROGER (WINKS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it. He takes the tool kit from the Clerk and drops it. The Cl watches Roger chase down all the parts: what a dolt. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger puts the tool set in his trunk...then stops. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing is - I missed out. (turns to CAMERA) It's like everyone else was there the day they taught all this stuff. How to look inside acar.Or a furnace. Or a rocketship.But the guys like Steve, youknow.They were born knowing allthis- and now they're laughing. (MORE)
ROGER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all go down to the Competent Guys' Tavern and compare notes. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VANS and PICKUP TRUCKS just like Steve's are parked outsi A STEVE LOOKALIKE gets out and goes in, greeting ANOTHER STEVE also arriving. LAUGHTER pours out from inside. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve rings the bell. Elaine tries opening the door. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on other side) I'm sorry - the door's stuck. STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can fix that. He checks it out, taps it in one place and opens the door Elaine steps aside, enchanted -- -- as Roger drives up and sees this. And the pain in his heart is something we can feel. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power's back on. Steve pulls the cover off the HVAC assem Roger is sorting through the 53-piece tool set he bought has no idea what to do with. STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you've got a minute, sir. I'd like to show you something. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up tool kit) Should I bring these? STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't be -- (then as all the parts FALL OUT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- necessary.     57 ROGER (LOOKS DOWN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The latch broke. STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can fix that. Roger puts the tool kit down. Joins Steve. STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's your problem right there. (POINTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got calcification in your pullet- beam header grommets. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was afraid of that. Steve looks at him. One of those sideways looks. STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you gotta do is jack up your laminate bolts and remove the calcification on the stress points. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (while Steve takes SOME MEASUREMENTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course when he says "you," he doesn't mean "me." I don't have jacks. I don't have winches. And Steve has got like fifty kinds of each, right on his truck. If society collapsed, the Steves of the world will be living in nice sturdy shelters that they built with their own hands, eating food that they grew or caught. And I'll be getting shredded to death by wolverines. STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go. He reaches down. Pulls out a fuse assembly, holds it up.
STEVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go. Back in business in no time. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is packing up his truck. Roger is about to go back INSIDE WHEN: KID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, look! Look what Steve made me! A working battleship made entirely out of Coke cans! Roger looks. It is a working battleship made from Coke ca KID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so neat! Thanks, Steve! The kid runs off. Roger looks at Elaine. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have a kid? ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve got him from the truck. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave rides up front with Steve. Talks to CAMERA. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because Steve can fix things, doesn't mean he's shallow and doesn't have any concerns. All guys have concerns. Deep concerns. STEVE (LOOKS OVER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like SportsTalk? Mike the Moose? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell yeah. Steve gives him a look. Turns on the radio.
CALLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just sayin' those owners better never run into me. Because God help 'em, man.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE THE MOOSE
dialogues.text: -- and we'll pick up on that and more, right after the news. CALLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it, man. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIKE THE MOOSE flips a switch; turns to Dave.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE THE MOOSE
dialogues.text: Three months ago, the Marlins traded a guy named Rufino Lupenza to the Yankees, for some minor league players and cash. I grant you it was a rotten trade. I grant you the Yankees seem to have this, this knack for making brilliant deals year after year. But three months? (pops in a tape) The Marlins are over it. The Yankees are over it. The players and their families are over it -- but just check this out. CALLER (ON TAPE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy was a workhorse! He filled in wherever he was needed and he never got hurt! And when he got hurt, he played hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE THE MOOSE
dialogues.text: (ON TAPE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I got a post card from him here at the station. He says they're all doing fine: Lucita's got the kids in their new school already and they all seem happy. She even found an Ecuadorean grocery she likes. CALLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grocery -- the guy batted 340, from both sides. (MORE)
CALLER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His on-base percentage was in the 4's, with a rocket arm on defense and an awareness of the field like nobody's business. And they trade him for minor leaguers? For untested, greenhorn punks who can barely even --

dialogues.speaker: MIKE THE MOOSE
dialogues.text: (pauses the tape) That guy's pretty normal. He cues forward, plays. A GUY CALLER, fighting tears.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE THE MOOSE
dialogues.text: (ON RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just have to move on, Stan. CALLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .I try to - I'm trying. But I just can't make sense of this... Mike the Moose stops the tape.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE THE MOOSE
dialogues.text: These are guys you wouldn't see crying even at a funeral. Guys who can't bring themselves to hug their own children. And they're beside themselves. (shakes his head) And all over a meaningless trade... DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaningless? Mike the Moose looks at him. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger and Gene are watching the KNICKS/HEAT game. Big bag of Doritos between them. TV ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .seventy-seven per cent from the line during the regular season, and a red-hot eighty-three per cent during the playoffs. ROGER
