dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop saying that!

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER SIDEKICK
dialogues.text: -- and in the fourth quarter of the playoffs, that number is even higher -- GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop saying that! TV ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they really picked the wrong guy to foul, at this crucial point in such a crucial game.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER AND GENE
dialogues.text: Stop saying that! TV ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dribbles. He sets -- he dribbles again... Roger and Gene lean forward. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on come on come on comeoncomeon -- GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss the shot miss the shot miss the shot come on and miss the shot -- TV ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and the Knicks call time out. They lean back in their seats; breathe some relief. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine and Kelly are addressing INVITATIONS by hand. Dave sits on the counter, listens in. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't know the players. The players don't know them - yet they idolize these people. They follow them from team to team -- and they know more about these teams than they know about their own families. They might not even know if they have families. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not during the playoffs anyway.
ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amen to that; then) And what gets me is, they think - they really think - that whether a team wins or loses or not depends on how much they personally care about them. Like if they don't care, the team can't win. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's true. They look over - see him on the counter. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's true. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true that the level of concern a guy shows for his team can affect the outcome of the game. (then off their looks) I mean not just one guy - but lots of guys. All the guys who care about the team combined, if they really care, can make a difference on the scoreboard. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's crazy. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hops off the counter) -- Follow me. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger and Gene and the game are FROZEN IN PLACE. Dave sta in the doorway with Elaine and Kelly. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time ever, through the use of highly advanced technology, we will be able to see the actual Concern Rays emanating from the minds of Roger and Gene, in their attempt to affect the outcome of this upcoming - and totally critical - foul shot.

The PICTURE CHANGES as though a filter has been slipped o the lens. Then we BEGIN TO SEE THE ACTUAL RAYS emanating from Roger's and Gene's foreheads and traveling into the screen. The rays are colored BLUE. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These Concern Rays go straight into the television screen where they join the combined Concern Rays of all the other guy fans watching this game right now. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: A MAP OF THE UNITED STATES
dialogues.text: Where all the CITIES representing major markets LIGHT UP FORM ARCS, like airline flight routes, connecting RED or BLUE CONCERN RAYS from each city, and sending them to MIA DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in front of map) Then the rays are transmitted to the actual arena itself, all arriving at the same moment regardless of any geographic or time zone differences. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave reports as BLUE AND RED CONCERN RAYS materialize fro the sky and descend on the arena, covering the roof. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it is here, at the arena, where the combined Concern Rays from both teams' fans will be measured - not just for quantity, but for quality. Because this - as every Guy must believe - is what wins ball games.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ROGER AND GENE AT THE TV
dialogues.text: Dave steps away and the PICTURE UN-FREEZES. TV ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sets...he takes the shot...it's UP -- ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Come on come on come on ---
GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss the shot miss the shot miss the SHOT --

dialogues.speaker: APPEAR AND CONVERGE ON IT, IN A MIGHTY STRUGGLE FOR DOMIN
dialogues.text: TV ANNOUNCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and he misses! He misses! It bounces off the rim and Miami wins the game! What a comeback! A field day for the Heat! Roger and Gene leap up and scream. High fives, victory da Dave looks at Elaine and Kelly - who look at each other.. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get back to those invitations. KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm with you. They turn, go back to the kitchen. The celebration goes o CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave walks down a terminal corridor among hurrying PASSEN DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's one thing women don't know about when it comes to guys, it's the public rest room problem. And we're here to clear that up right now. He stops outside a MEN'S REST ROOM, which is currently cl for maintenance. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This room is a private hell for a countless number of guys -- yet the women in their lives are completely in the dark about it. (MORE)
DAVE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before we go inside, let's talk with a leading social scientist, so that what we're about to show you sounds a little more official. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave is at the honor bar with the SAME BRITISH GUY. The words "Leading Social Scientist" APPEAR under him this ti

dialogues.speaker: LEADING SOCIAL SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: One has to understand that the act of emptying one's bladder goes deep to the very roots of masculinity. It is an important territorial statement that males are genetically programmed to carry out. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: LEADING SOCIAL SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: In fact, many of my colleagues believe the reason that dogs howl at the moon is because they can't go up there and urinate on it -- which is not, however, a theory which I embrace. But guess who gets all the grant money every year. The bastards... He stares off into space. A bitter man. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um...you were saying?

dialogues.speaker: LEADING SOCIAL SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: I didn't want this job. Twenty years, in the social sciences? And what was everybody else doing -- they were getting laid. They were going to bed with women. And what have I been doing -- applying for matching grants. And not getting them. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LEADING SOCIAL SCIENTIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Applying for any grants at all - and not getting those either. Meanwhile all the "cool dudes" are laughing! CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honda Accords fill the lot. TWO MORE drive up and a SCIEN gets out of each. They hail each other and go in together As they pull open the door, LAUGHTER spills out from insi

dialogues.speaker: LEADING SOCIAL SCIENTIST, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The bastards... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a SATELLITE DISH on top. Dave is with JOHN MADDE DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With me now is the great John Madden -- legendary coach of football's Oakland Raiders and veteran network analyst for CBS Sports and now the Fox Sports Network. John, thanks for coming by today. JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy to be here Dave. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, you heard what our leading expert said about this particular anxiety that guys have regarding bathrooms in general and public ones in particular. Any thoughts? JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's exactly right, Dave. I mean the guy was a little loopy but he hit the nail on the head. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So an airport bathroom presents a specific kind of challenge.
JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worst kind, Dave, and in a lotta ways. Because a guy's main goal is to get in and outta there without having to deal in any other way with any other guy - and in an airport bathroom especially, with the turnover rate they've got, he's up against some pretty mean odds. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't agree more, John. Let's go INSIDE -- CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TECHNICIANS wearing headsets. Dave and John sit by a BANK OF MONITORS. There's a TELESTRATOR for John. JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Now this angle here, we're outside the bathroom and the maintenance guy's just about to open it up. We SEE THE AREA OUTSIDE THE MEN'S ROOM, WITH "CLOSED FOR MAINTENANCE" SIGNS IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH. A JANITOR star removing the signs as a BUSINESS TRAVELER heads over. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's our first candidate now -- INTERCUT WITH:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John diagrams the action, marking up the screen like a football play while the action unfolds. JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay now the leadoff guy, he's gonna come in, he's gonna see the open field and he's gonna swing wide right to grab a spot against the wall. He's got one flank covered this way and for now he's feelin' pretty good -- and of course by doin' that, he's also settin' the tone for everything that happens after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rГўВЂВў . 68. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the main thing we're looking for, John. What does each individual guy feel he needs to get out of this. JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well the crucial thing here, is makin' sure there's no eye contact. I mean none - zero. These guys'll look up, they'll look down, they'll look straight ahead -- but a guy would rather have you poke both his eyes out with burning hot fire tongs, Dave, than to give the next guy over a reason to think you might be lookin' at him in a public bathroom. For reasons that oughtta be pretty darn obvious. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obvious indeed. Now here comes Guy Number Two -- The SECOND GUY comes in; John diagrams the call. JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Guy Number Two, what he's gonna do is, he's gonna come in, see the first guy in position along the wall and right away he's gonna line up wide on the opposite side. This is a best case scenario here, something both these guys can appreciate. Plus they've opened up the middle for the third guy -- The THIRD GUY comes in. John diagrams his path to the mid urinal. The Guy goes there. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about eye contact in this situation. JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you're still not likely to encounter any, but again if you do, that's what that buffer zone on either side of him's for. And all three of 'em are feelin' pretty lucky to have it, I can tell you that. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Now if things stay like this...
JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If things stay like this, you're fine - and if this were some small commuter airport, y'know late at night or somethin', then these guys could possibly even be home free. But we're talkin' Miami International here, this is the big time, we're talking about 747's, DC-10's, the big jumbo jets dumpin' off three- four hundred people at a clip. So everybody's gonna be next to somebody, which is the last thing any of these guys want. You're in a critical mass situation, and this is where a lotta mistakes get made. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which brings us to Guy Number Four. Here he comes -- JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and there he goes... Guy #4 spins around and leaves. John and Dave watch; then DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now one thing that I know we're going to get asked, John, especially from women, is whether, as guys, we're aware of how utterly stupid this kind of behavior really is. JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I think we know, Dave. Don't you think we know? DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we do. JOHN MADDEN (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have to be stupid not to. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We did that. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave walks the campus. Threads through GORGEOUS COLLEGE GIRLS who don't know he's there. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's anything that causes more anguish in a guy than sports anguish, and public restroom anguish, and hardware store anguish, it's the day that he realizes that somehow his life is half over now, and no matter what he tries to tell himself, he's not young anymore and he's never going to be young again. (then he stops) And as any guy'll tell you - it sucks. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUY IN A SUIT, alone in here. Faint ELEVATOR MUSIC play ELEVATOR GUY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got used to having the Beatles and Stones called 'classic rock.' Then I heard Elvis Costello on an Oldies station. I figured, okay - who cares - at least it's on somewhere. But then I hear "London Calling," on Muzak. By the Clash. On Muzak. (SHRUGS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what the hell. I'm in a suit and I go around all day explaining peoples' 401K plans to them. And Sting's doing commercials for Jaguar. He shakes his head; it's hopeless. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BARBER talks while cutting Dave's hair.
BARBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way I see it, it's like menopause, right? Except men get it different. It doesn't show, y'see? The cramps don't come, the hot and cold flashes, and you don't have your magazines and drug stores filled with helpful stuff to do about it. But something comes, and it hits every guy who's living whether he likes it or not. Whether he knows it or not. Guy can lose his bleepin' mind if he doesn't watch out. He gets a mirror to show Dave the back. Gives him time to get philosophical. BARBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know? Maybe it's for the better. Maybe whoever designed all this, was afraid to let the men in on what was gonna be happening. Like if we knew, we'd bail or something. You know, ahead of time. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BARTENDER wipes the bar down in front of Dave. BARTENDER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just telling you what I see. Every lousy day. A guy'll come in and sit down, right where you are. He loosens up a little and then it comes. The road not taken. Unexamined choices. An unfulfilled life. And other guys, they'll come in and don't say a word. The ones who just stare at the mirror. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds pretty bleak. BARTENDER (SHRUGS; THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it goes back to the old times. Ancient times, you know? When nobody was expected to live past forty. You got to forty? You died. (MORE)
BARTENDER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now that men aren't doing that, there's a lot more shit up ahead, and none of it looks good so they go freak out and make a mess of things -- they'll quit their jobs or walk out on their marriages or make some other idiot grandstand move. None of them are happy and every single one of them wishes he did something else with his life and can't figure out how it got this way. Every single one of them. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hotshot LAWYER is dictating a memo to his SECRETARY. LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .therefore please be advised that in reference to the aforementioned subject matter, as per the original agreement dated 7 March Two Thousand, -- His Secretary stops writing. Waits. LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...7 March Two Thousand... SECRETARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um. You said that already. LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) I started here on the 7th of March. Fifteen years ago... SECRETARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well - Happy Anni-- LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell am I doing. Why did I even think this would be a good idea -- to work my ass off every single day of my life? So I could come in here and dictate letters like this? SECRETARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not all like this. You do a lot of good...     73 LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what does it get me -- a twin- turbo convertible that I don't even get to drive, because I'm always traveling and renting shitbox cars in other cities where all I do is take clients out to lunch and tell them how to negotiate their golden parachutes? You ever sit in the driver's seat of one of those renta cars? SECRETARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well my husband usually does the -- LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brand new cars, not even two thousand miles on them, and already they drive like camels. The seat's got no cushion left already, and you're lucky if you don't need a chiropractor after twenty minutes in one. What do people do in those things? SECRETARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I could get you something. You want something? LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I want something. I want the number of that hang-gliding place out on Route 33. SECRETARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go hang gliding? LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to teach hang gliding. SECRETARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't know you did that. LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do that. I want to do that. I've always wanted to do that, and lots of other things too -- only I'm stuck doing this all day long. And I don't even know what this is half the time, just that I have to spend every waking hour doing it. So you tell me -- where the hell does hang gliding fit into that.
SECRETARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um. Saturdays? LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a break. SECRETARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he starts to leave) Where are you going? LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have done this a long time ago. SECRETARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the letter? LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put in the usual bullshit. Nobody's gonna read it anyway. He's gone. She sits there. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY LAKE lifts a titanium frame up onto the back of a pickup. Part of it catches on the lift gate and he SWEARS kicking it. About to really lay into it when the LAWYER drives up in his twin turbo convertible and gets out. LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. We're closed. LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned; watches him) -- It's two thirty in the afternoon. JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. I don't make the rules. LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you the owner? JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. I do make the rules. We're closed.
LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sees he means it) Look, there has to -- I really want to learn this -- I just quit my job to learn this. JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be my guest - learn it. He kicks the frame again, walks off. The Lawyer watches. LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you do this? This is the perfect job! JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah right. Driving around in a rusted worthless pickup truck that's about to be repossessed anyway, while a guy like you, my own age, is going around in a Porsche Carrera. LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you get to fly. JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you get to fly. I get to hoof this shit up and down these godforsaken hilltops listening to stockbrokers brag about getting lap dances from college coeds, and charging the whole thing through the company expense account -- while I can't even deduct my blood pressure medication. That's what I get to do. He kicks a rock in the road, which almost feels good enou so he kicks another one -- but this one is buried in the dirt like an iceberg and doesn't budge -- JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, SHIT! -- and he falls down hobbling on one knee instead. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny Lake waits on the examining table, holding ice aga his leg. The Lawyer sits on the extra chair reading EXOTI ISLANDS MAGAZINE.
He holds up a PHOTO: a Guy in a hammock, in Paradise. LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this. JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that right. The Lawyer shakes his head; flips the page. JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. (then on Lawyer's look; he shrugs) You don't think he's gonna... LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know. Have to use the -- LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glove? (then off his look) You hurt your knee. He already took the x-rays. JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if something's broken. LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's not going in that way. You don't do a rectal to set a guy's leg. Still the guy looks doubtful. The ORTHOPEDIC SURGEON - British, familiar - comes in, with a fresh X-RAY. ORTHOPEDIC SURGEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you've done quite a number on yourself. Want to see? JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I. I wouldn't know what the hell I'm looking at. You're the one who went to medical school. ORTHOPEDIC SURGEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't remind me. (then on their looks) What. You think I like this? (MORE)     77

dialogues.speaker: ORTHOPEDIC SURGEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The medical profession? Owing my life to the insurance cartel while the rest of the world thinks I'm so stinking rich? LAWYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.. .aren't you? ORTHOPEDIC SURGEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of courseIam - I'm an orthopedic surgeon!Ijust don't like people assumingit! (THENASHIS BEEPER GOESOFF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this -- I am so sick of this bloody thing I can't even tell you! Because every time it goes off it means I have to stop doing one thing I don't want to be doing, and start doing another thing I don't want to be doing. You call that a life? They look at him. Don't know what to say. ORTHOPEDIC SURGEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Let me show you something. (puts down the x-ray, goes to a drawer) I've been working on this during my free time. Not like I get any. He gets an accordion-style envelope; takes out a REAM OF TYPED PAGES. Hands it over to Johnny Lake. JOHNNY LAKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? ORTHOPEDIC SURGEON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? It's a screenplay! This'll blow the lid off the orthopedic surgery industry! Look - look here -- (takes it back; flips THROUGH)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- no wait, this part's better. No -- here! Here you go. Read this and tell me if you don't --
He looks up. They're gone. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lot is filled with Ford Fiestas. The Lawyer and Johnn Lake drive up. When they pull the door open there's WHINI from inside... Then the BARTENDER FROM BEFORE comes out, storms past the and throws his rag down hard as he gets the hell out of t and away from that shit job. As Dave walks into frame, starts over to his car. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay! Well it looks like it's time to talk about sex. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Will you knock it off? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave gets out of his car and walks towards the mall. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the sake of any younger viewers who might still be paying attention, during this next segment we will be using certain euphemisms to describe a natural and wonderful thing that happens among grownups - grownups besides your parents, that is. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave walks along all the COSMO'S, REDBOOKS, etc. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably the fastest growing sector of the U.S. economy is the sector that conducts surveys asking women (MORE)     DAVE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: what is wrong with men. And in all those surveys, there is one main area that shows up constantly at the top of the charts. (he stops, pulls a MAGAZINE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Euphemisms. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave walks up the aisles filled with delectable things. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: when I say "euphemisms," I of course am not suggesting that guys don't have them. Guys have plenty of euphemisms. Most guys have more euphemisms in a single day - and here I am thinking of a day that occurred in the summer between ninth and tenth grades - than some women have in a lifetime - or longer, in the case of certain Math Teachers. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave walks outside, past a line of SCHOOLKIDS off a BUS. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It all goes back to a time, millions of years ago, when primitive males often had to complete their part of the equation quickly and right away stand ready to fight off attackers. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave walks past glassed-in DISPLAYS of CAVEMAN LIFE. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, however, women want euphemisms too -- and this ability in males is no longer as prized as it once was. (MORE)
DAVE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, when modern women describe the qualities they're looking for in the ideal man, the phrase "a real fast shooter" is usually pretty far down the list. (THEN STOPPING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally, it fell to guys to do something about this. So, naturally - they did. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave stands outside while Kelly and Gene come back from walking their dog. In a hurry. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: one technique for holding back the inevitable, is when the guy - just when he is about to have his euphemism - will hurl himself violently into an iron bed railing, and raise a lump on his head the size of a golf ball. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come in the room, shedding clothes. He lifts her, carries her to the bed -- with nothing but pillows agains the wall. He stops, panicked... GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing there! CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave watches the LIGHT GO OFF. Turns back to the CAMERA. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In cases where there aren't any iron railings, a good backup technique can be found right on the end of the cold wet nose of the trusted family dog. CAMERA PANS to the window where we hear:
KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...yes... GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .yesyesyesyes...yesyesyesyes... KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .just hold on...yes... GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .yesyesyesyesYEEE00000WWWW!!! CAMERA PANS back to Dave. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are also mental techniques -- CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger and Elaine are under the sheets. Some good early MOANING.. .as Dave comes in, holding a mike, interview st DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the most time honored and reliable mental delaying styles, is the Baseball Method -- (taps Roger's shoulder) -- how's it going, Champ. Roger pokes his head out of the blanket; stays active fro the neck down. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - yeah hi. (ACKNOWLEDGES CAMERA;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: then to Dave) Well, the baseball thing. I mean a while ago I was into that - big time. You know, fooling around with different lineups, mixing up the batting order - like thinking about what would happen if you took your cleanup guy and made him eighth or something -- just something stupid like that, you know? Stuff you'd never really do. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that did the trick.
ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hell yeah. I mean I could go all night - literally all night - just shuffling my pitching staff around, or thinking about who I might try and sign at the winter meetings. Hang on -- He goes under the blanket; pays more attention to Elaine. then comes back. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing is, it got stale. And I found after a while I wasn't enjoying sex or baseball that much. And you don't want to mess with that stuff. DAVE (CAN'T DISAGREE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you do instead? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Math problems. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? (off his nod) You mean like if a train leaves Chicago at one o'clock and another train leaves Denver at two o'clock and they're going at different speeds? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) I can't do train ones. I always end up imagining this beautiful girl on the train - and it makes things even worse. Elaine stops. Pops her head out. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: what beautiful girl. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You, Elaine. The girl on the train is always you. ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Roger...
Roger gives Dave a close call look...then goes back to wo CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave helps himself, makes a sandwich. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you can see, a lot of guys are making a tremendous effort here - and yet, according to certain standards they are still, basically, lame as hell on almost every single count. The reason for this is simple: women set the standards. (takes a bite) And not just bedroom standards -- all standards. Because women invented standards. Remember the Dawn of Guys? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long shadows. PRIMATE WOMEN are still at it, pounding roo and dealing with PRIMATE KIDS. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primate Elaine, picking up around the cave. She stumbles something gross... finally has had it. PRIMATE ELAINE (SUBTITLED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primate Elaine addresses the OTHERS. All SUBTITLES. PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking. We need some standards around here. PRIMATE KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are standards?

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE BLONDE WOMAN
dialogues.text: What is 'thinking?' The others turn, look at her. Look back at Primate Blaine PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standards are like rules. Things they'll have to do. And things they'll have to stop doing. PRIMATE KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about "no leaving your dirty smelly loincloths wherever you feel like it, and expecting me to do something about it?" Can that be a standard? PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That can be one of the first.

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE BLONDE WOMAN
dialogues.text: How about "No gnawing on a fish head during sex?" PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are all kinds of things we can get them to do. PRIMATE LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? They're stronger than we are. PRIMATE KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smell stronger maybe.

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE BLONDE WOMAN
dialogues.text: (off their laughter) I like the smell. PRIMATE LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the men, or the rotten fish? PRIMATE KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a difference? More laughing; then they turn back to Primate Elaine. PRIMATE KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how will we make them go along? Most of them can't even remember which cave to come home to every night. How are they going to remember rules?
PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll give them a Look. PRIMATE LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look? PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A special look. A 'Certain Look.' PRIMATE KELLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we look at them every day. And they still do whatever they want. PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as the others agree) I've been working on this. Watch. She turns to Primate Blonde Woman, who is holding a gourd On the Look, the Blonde drops the gourd. PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? And she wasn't even doing anything. Agreements and "Wows" go all around. PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now who's with me. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE GOURD AGAIN.
dialogues.text: CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Primate Guys come back lugging ANIMAL PARTS. Each now has his own ROCK, instead of the giant jagged slabs. PRIMATE GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing later. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Probably just stare at the fire.
PRIMATE GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of us are going over to Primate Blonde Woman's cave to see what she does with those gourds. Want to come? PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Can't. Primate Elaine's ancestors are still here. PRIMATE GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bummer. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it. (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are so Ice Age... CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primate Roger watches Primate Elaine examine his NEW ROCK Her PRIMATE MOM AND DAD hover on the edge of the discussi PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it. What was wrong with the other one. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's better. It's an upgrade.

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE ELAINE'S FATHER
dialogues.text: What did he say it was called? PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An 'upgrade.' An improvement on a previous design.

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE ELAINE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: What? What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE ELAINE'S FATHER
dialogues.text: (to his wife) An upgrade. An grade. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Primate Elaine) The guy said there are newer ones coming out that'll make even this one look primitive. They're getting lighter and rounder every epoch.     87

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE ELAINE'S FATHER
dialogues.text: What guy. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Primate Discount Manny.

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE ELAINE'S FATHER
dialogues.text: (MUTTERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy he must have seen this one coming... PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad. (then to Primate Roger) I just wanted to know what the difference is between this one and the one you had. You were so excited about it when you got it, and now you've gotten rid of it -- and the only difference I can see is where this one has these markings painted on. She holds it up; something like BASEBALL SEAMS going arou PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those make it so it travels better. PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Painted on? (off his look) -- What'd it cost you. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. A couple wildebeeste steaks and handful of seeds of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE ELAINE'S FATHER
dialogues.text: I told you. (then to his wife) Did I say he was a bum? PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's a bum. Are you calling me a bum?

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE ELAINE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: No one's calling anyone a bum.

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE ELAINE'S FATHER
dialogues.text: I'm just visiting. You do what you want.
PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Who do you think killed your dinner tonight? PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Just take it back. Please. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't do that! All sales are final! PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can explain it to him. Tell him he can keep the steaks, but we want the seeds back.

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE ELAINE'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: (to Primate Roger) I don't mean to meddle. But you should listen to your wife.

dialogues.speaker: PRIMATE ELAINE'S FATHER
dialogues.text: That's meddling! That's meddling! (then to Primate Roger) -- But in this case she's right. PRIMATE ELAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to her parents) Look will you both stop? (then to Primate Roger) Just take this back. All right? PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is totally unreasonable! (THEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I get it. Don't tell me -- it's your time in the moon cycle again -- He stops cold. Stunned by her CERTAIN LOOK. History's fir in SLOW MOTION, FROM SEVERAL ANGLES, the way they do it w buildings explode in much bigger movies. PRIMATE ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'll take it back. She smiles. FREEZE IMAGE. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave strolls among the SHOPPERS, TOURISTS etc. He has the ROCK with him; tosses it unconsciously like a baseball.
DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is basically where we stand today. The only difference is, we have way more standards. (gives the ROCK to a KID passing by) There are social standards, about being sensitive - remembering anniversaries, listening during conversations, not eating soup with your hands, or sitting around in your underwear when company's over. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave goes up the escalator; walks through the kind of 'Ho Stylings' section where no other guy would go. Everything he talks about is on display in some form. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And there are thousands of standards for domestic life, involving even more totally un-guy concepts -- like curtains, bedspreads, napkins, special hangers, little soaps shaped like fruit, and decorative boxes that hold tissues that already come in a box. While guys, left on their own in the wild, will develop lifestyles that don't involve any of these things. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLLEGE ROGER and COLLEGE GENE stand in their doorway. Th is one window, a lot of dust and nothing else. COLLEGE GENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know just what this place needs. COLLEGE ROGER (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hockey sticks. They turn around to go buy hockey sticks. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RABBIT on a lawn chair drinks beer out of an ashtray. College Roger and College Gene play Indoor Death Hockey; slamming into walls, scattering NEWSPAPERS and PIZZA BOXE as their IMAGE FREEZES. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of course, even by the most basic standards, these two are living like savages. But they honestly don't know this -- because Guys, in their natural state, aren't any more aware of domestic standards than a trout would be aware of the stock market. And this causes women a lot of concern. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEATTLE GIRL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take laundry. To him his clean clothes are ready when he's ready to go get them. And they can dry the rest of the way in the drawer. But they don't dry the rest of the way in the drawer, they sit there in damp musty unfolded balls and he doesn't even mind, and I can't figure that out. What is the matter with folding something? What is the matter with waiting for it to be dry? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave unloads a laundry basket on the bed. Starts folding the clean clothes and making piles. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laundry's a big issue - and a deep and puzzling mystery to guys. My own wife Michelle, for instance, is an accomplished sportswriter and mother of an extremely young child, yet she is still able to maintain a vigorous clothes-cleaning regimen bordering on the super-human. And I'm not allowed near the stuff.
MICHELLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comes in with more CLOTHES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right. She dumps out the clothes, sees what he's doing and takes over, doing it better. Dave picks up a random BLOUSE, sho a LABEL with lots of printing on it. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are clearly secret codes, that women intuitively understand but cannot adequately explain -- just like how a lot of guys understand the Infield Fly Rule, without being able to explain that. MICHELLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can explain the Infield Fly Rule. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're special, Sweetheart. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave anchors a semi circle with Sidra, Mia, Karla E and L They take turns focus group style. SIDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think they're just like tapeworms. You know? I mean tapeworms are just tapeworms - that's all they are, and all they'll ever be. They're just these repulsive little parasitic beasts and nobody expects anything different from them - because people know that's their nature. And it's the same way with guys - although a tapeworm's more likely to help clean out the garage. LILA (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have to be the biggest and they have to be the best. And they can never back down from a challenge. Ever.     92 KARLA E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sleep with your sister and wonder what's wrong with that. MIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will make a game out of anything. A contest out of anything. Give them a grain of sand and they will figure out some game with it. LILA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they'll argue over the rules. KARLA E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off their agreement) They leave their dirty dishes everywhere. I can't believe the places I'll find some crusted over cereal bowl with yuckola blobs of God knows what in them. And the thing is, from his point of view? They really do get cleaned by magic! Because I can't take seeing them sit there, so I clean them. SIDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Karla E) I just get him to wash my car when that stuff happens. KARLA E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart he could wash my car with his tongue and it still wouldn't make up for where I find those dishes sometimes. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (while they commiserate) So now that we've heard your thoughts. The frustration, the exasperation... the obvious question comes to mind: Why go through it? Why have guys in your life at all? They look at him. MIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You mean as a choice? You mean like a mature adult choice to have a guy in your life? In spite of everything?     93 SIDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like trying to borrow money from you, after you've broken up, so he can buy something for his new girlfriend? And wondering what the problem was with that? I mean like really not knowing? Dave looks at her. They all do. Until -- LILA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you why. There is no good reason, that's why. The others turn, look her way. LILA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I mean don't get me wrong. They really can be fun. You know, like a big stupid dog can be fun. I mean not everything has to be so serious in life. You want to be able to do more with someone than just read book reviews together - which is something a guy would never do anyway. (then as the others LISTEN CLOSER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what a guy will do? Is at eleven o'clock at night he'll show up at your door and bring cheese steaks. And he doesn't care that you look all rumply and dreadful from not expecting anyone. He might not even remember that you're a vegetarian and don't eat cheese steaks -- but that doesn't really matter either. Because the point is he wanted one, and he can't come out and say it but he didn't want to eat it alone. MIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're the person he thought of. LILA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off her look; nods) I can't tell you what that feels like, when they do that. (a beat; and then) I swear, if they knew how adorable they are sometimes, they'd be dangerous. I mean -- more dangerous. The other Girls think about that. Considering...
SIDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Bullshit. They're tapeworms. The rest of them agree and all high-five her. Dave leans back from the fray, turns to the CAMERA. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's time for the conclusion now. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SIGN says "UNDER NEW MANAGEMENT." Dave is on top of the hill, in a rig that the EX-LAWYER is fastening him into. DAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now you know where things stand. You've learned a little bit about guys, and the critical roles they've played in the past and in modern society today. And for better or worse, they're here with us to stay -- so the best thing you can do about it, is continue to learn about them - by coming to see this movie lots and lots of times, and bringing more and more of your friends back every time you do. Because the more people that understand guys, the better for everyone. And the more people that -- (as the Lawyer launches HIM) -- WHOAAAAAAAALII

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off he goes. . .right out of frame, and -- FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC AND END CREDITS BEGIN, AS --
dialogues.text: CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: A PICTURE OF ROGER AND ELAINE, IN ROGER'S CAR
dialogues.text: SUBTITLE: Roger now owns a 104-piece tool set, and he has successfully attempted to change his first switchplate.
SUBTITLE: Elaine has an open line of credit with Steve.

dialogues.speaker: A PICTURE OF GENE AND KELLY, AT A DANCE CLASS
dialogues.text: SUBTITLE: Gene and Kelly won the Fred and Ginger Award in three straight ballroom competitions. Gene was right; the belong together.

dialogues.speaker: A PICTURE OF SHERYL CROW, IN CONCERT
dialogues.text: SUBTITLE: Sheryl Crow gave a concert in Central Park for half a million people a while back. We weren't there, but we have it on CD.

dialogues.speaker: A PICTURE OF RICHARD M. NIXON WAVING GOODBYE
dialogues.text: SUBTITLE: Richard M. Nixon was finally elected President 1968. He held that position until August, 1974, when he resigned in disgrace.

dialogues.speaker: A PICTURE OF AGENTS LEOPOLD AND STEARNS
dialogues.text: SUBTITLE: Agent Leopold and Agent Stearns were fired by t FBI for gross incompetence. They now work in network television.

dialogues.speaker: A PICTURE OF THE BRITISH GUY WHO PLAYED EVERY EXPERT
dialogues.text: SUBTITLE: This man is not really an expert. If you see hi don't listen to any of his opinions.

dialogues.speaker: A PICTURE OF A BALLPLAYER, WITH HIS FACE BLURRED OUT
dialogues.text: SUBTITLE: Rufino Lupenza is an imaginary ballplayer, crea by the filmmakers to prove a point. However, if he did ex and if he were any good, the Yankees probably would get h And that would suck.

dialogues.speaker: A PICTURE OF JOHN MADDEN ON A TV SCREEN. WHICH THEN COMES
dialogues.text: ALIVE -- JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now these are the kinda end credits you like to see. You got the final update thing goin', where you find out how all the characters you've been watchin' are gonna turn out. You got good music, a lively kinda feel, and maybe most of all, the movie itself isn't too long -- He reacts now, looking down at the TAIL CREDITS as they s speeding up.
JOHN MADDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- that's how you know it's a real movie, in my book. That's how you know it's not some boring kinda art piece made by these tortured head case kids fresh outta film school -- you're not gonna come outta this theater talkin' about symbolism, or the use of darkness and light or any kinda mumbo-jumbo like that -- you come out of this movie and you're laughin'. And that's what I like in a movie - a movie that's funny but it doesn't take forever, you know? You still got some time to do somethin' after, maybe go get somethin' to eat, y'know? Because the guys behind the thing knew enough not to drag on and on and -- CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: As the MUSIC FADES.. .and it's QUIET. A good quiet...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hey what do you know? We got through the whole entire thing without saying "booger." FADE OUT: THE END
